, is a public charter school in Redlands, California serving students in grades seven through twelve. It is one of the oldest charter high schools in the state of California.
At the start of the 2012/2013 academic year
in two programs: the middle school and the high school. The enrollment is capped at 200 by the school’s chart

The middle school program, a farm-based program called
sori tradition, is located on nine
acres of land at the corner of Iowa

The land, part of a former dairy farm, is on a long term lease from the city of Redlands, which acquired the property under the Measure O bond initiative to retain open space in the city. The middle school's lease is for a portion of the 40 acre property, now a part of the Heritage Park,
a part of the Redlands Emerald Necklace plan.

Middle school classrooms are located in a converted house and garage. There is a farm store, located on Iowa Street, which sells produce from the school’s vegetable garden and eggs from the school’s chicken flock. There is also a woodworking workshop, a greenhouse, a new chicken coop, goat pens, and a large barn, formerly used for milking a herd of dairy cows. This dairy barn is currently used for storage. With the exception of the coop, none of the buildings were built for their current purpose. None of the buildings are seismically reinforced.
n to the buildings, there is a quarter acre

vegetable garden, an outdoor stage, and a covered courtyard adjacent to the house and garage which is used for outdoor gatherings. On Saturdays, the school runs a farmers' market on a field adjacent to Orange Avenue. There are currently no athletic facilities at the middle school. The farm's water rights are unclear.

The Grove School, through its middle school

steward of Heritage Park. Like the relationship with MIR, the School and the Park have common founders with a common vision for the two facilities. The middle school is on Park land; in turn, the School serves as a living community supporting the Park through agricultural demonstration, animal husbandry, and architectural preservation, restoration, and adaptive reuse.

Today, there are five hundred students attending MIR and Grove but little if any signage or clear visibility of the presence of these schools. This is, partly, by design; the MIR campus, screened by citrus, blends into the surrounding landscape through the illusion of a grove.

The Grove's two programs, middle school and high school, are located on adjacent but not contiguous plots of land. Institutionally, they are one school but physically they tend to be isolated from one another.
Like the relationship of the Grove to MIR, the internal consistency of the Grove's own programs ought to b
e reflected in physical space; we intend to
s – the paths, crosswalks and circulation patterns –
between the Grove's middle school and high school programs.
The Grove School's middle school program is an agriculture-based land lab, following Maria Montessori's

(“earth child”) model for early adolescence. In addition to rigorous academics, students run a farm, selling vegetables and animals raised on the land. This document, a part of the “One Campus” conceptual campus development plan, describes the current situation of the agriculture program and outlines our plans to develop a certified organic commercial vegetable farm.

The farm at the Grove is slightly less than two acres. There is a 1.7 acre field and a quarter acre market garden on land leased from the City of Redlands’s Heritage Park. The property, purchased by city bond funds, was in the past a working dairy farm owned by the van
family. Thus the School’s farm is a part of the heritage of this land and we see the School’s role as stewards of the land.

Through the US Department of Education, the School has a formally recognized Agriculture Education Program. In addition, the school is a member of the San Bernardino County Farm Bureau (a part of the California Farm Bureau Federation), and an active chapter of

the Future Farmers of America (FFA) organization, the only FFA left in our area. A fully functioning commercial farm has always been a part of the vision for the school and is a part of Maria Montessori's idea for the adolescent workshop.
The School uses the farm as a "prepared environment" in Montessori terms, which allows students to gain real world experiences in the micro-world of the farm without being fully in the wider world.

The School's agriculture program is run by a teacher with dual responsibilities for both teaching agriculture-based middle school science classes and managing the farm. The position requires farming and teaching experience and, ideally, a Montessori background.
In grades 7-9, the School uses supervised agriculture experience as an integral component of its pedagogy, including project-based work, curriculum, and student leadership.

The students conduct hands-on projects at the farm, including the full value chain of planning, preparing, planting, weeding, harvesting, and selling of crops. Other student projects include, for example, animal husbandry and equipment maintenance and repair. These proficiencies support the California Technical Education (CTE) program, which intends to teach practical skills to secondary school students.
The grade 7-9 curriculum is centered around agriculture as well, although not exclusively. For instance, a science lesson on
inheritance in genetics may draw on experiments the students conducted, like

Students also gain leadership experience through the Future Farmers of America (FFA) organization. They develop leadership skills such as public speaking, planning meetings, and running the organization.
The existing market garden operation will continue to grow mixed vegetables for three primary internal markets: the School's lunch program, the School's farmer's market, and the School's farm store.

There is a farm store, located on Iowa Street, which sells produce from the school’s vegetable garden and eggs from the school’s chicken flock. On Saturdays, the school runs a farmers' market on a field adjacent to Orange Avenue. There is a commercial kitchen in the high school building, which is primarily used for a farm-to-table student lunch program serving both Montessori in Redlands and Grove students with food from the Grove's farm program.
The School intends to develop the larger field for
of, e.g., pumpkins, strawberries, and melons. We will explore selling to other potential customers including Bon
(the food concession at the Univ. of Redlands) and the Esri Cafe.
The School will pursue organic certification through the California Certified Organic Farmers organization.

The start-up phase of the expanded agriculture program, including the 1.7 acre field, will require significant capital investment and operating expenses that the School will not expect to recoup. Capital expenses include:
tractor (e.g., Kubota B7800 or similar) and implements: $19,000 - $25,000
Through the generosity of the City of Redlands, Jack and Laura

, and the Redlands Service Club Council, Heritage Park and the School received major physical plant improvements through a Service Club Council Work day on 27 April 2013. These improvements included grading the land, trees and irrigation, fencing around the entire property, new animal pens, greenhouse renovations, mulch, new pathways, improvements to the market garden, and other improvements.
Since the workday, the new 1.7 acre field has been

with the help of Jacinto Farms. Next, a cover crop, a vetch-based green manure mix, will be planted. The School plans to plant pumpkins in early July 2013, after turning over the cover crop, for an October 2013 pumpkin harvest.

In this current start-up phase, the agriculture program teacher will work with students to amend and prepare the soil, lay out the beds, establish a crop rotation, install the irrigation, acquire the necessary equipment, and work on other necessary facilities.

The School is in the process of establishing an Agriculture Advisory Board. This advisory board, which does not have administrative or policy authority, is intended to provide understanding between the School and the community we serve. The Grove’s Agriculture Advisory Board will provide balanced judgment to local problems and help give continuity and support to the Grove Agriculture Program. The structure and detailed functions of the board will be based on the California Department of Education’s High School Leadership Division “Agriculture Education Advisory Committee Manual.”

Board members may include a San Bernardino County Farm Bureau representative, one or more local farmers, and other interested parties especially individuals engaged in a significantly related occupation.

a single campus for the Grove School, bounded by Orange Avenue on the north, Barton Road to the south Iowa Street to the east, and

The main house (the brick mansard roofed building by the
, not the Barton Schoolhouse) has 6,500 square feet on three levels. The offices on the second and third floors are 267 sq. ft., 267 sq.

In addition to the main house, t
here are three offices in the 'stables' -- the outbuildings. The space is configurable; unlike the main building, the interior walls aren't load-bearing. Those offices are:
1,200 sq. ft. -- rented on a month-to-month lease
1,200 sq. ft. -- rented on a new five year lease

If we assume that we will occupy the office that is now on a month-to-month lease, combine it with the first floor of the main Barton House and the available office, we will have 5,573 square feet of usable space, more than in the current high school building.
The sale price is $3m, but the Vines would be willing to carve out the one acre orange grove at the corner and
Custard to lower the price to $2.2m. At $2.2m, the mortgage would be $10,189/month, assuming no money down and 3.75% interest.
The Barton Preschool pays $4,532/month in rent and we currently pay $6,000/month in rent; together that is enough to cover the mortgage.
We would still need to perform expensive renovations to the building, including adding an elevator, science labs, and configuring the existing space for classrooms.

The sale price is $3m, but the Vines would be willing to carve out the one acre orange grove at the corner and
Custard to lower the price to $2.2m. At $2.2m, the mortgage would be $10,189/month, assuming no money down and 3.75% interest.
